The  Project  will  address  citywide  deficiencies  in  basic  urban 
services  for  six  of  the  largest  urban  centers  in  Madhya  Pradesh. 
Direct  social  benefits  will  be  sustained  improvements  in  water 
supply,  sanitation,  garbage  collection,  and  disposal  within  the 
project cities. Indirect benefits will accrue through improved living 
conditions,  healthier  living  environments,  and  the  prospect  of 
improved  health  status  of  the  population.    The  Project  will  also 
assist the participating cities in undertaking participatory planning 
exercises  that  meet  the  needs  of  the  urban  poor.  Based  on 
successful  experience  in  other  states  in  India,  two  community-
level funds will be provided to support the  integrated upgrading of 
poor  settlements  for  improved  water  supply,  sanitation,  drains, 
and social services. 
 
Madhya  Pradesh  is  the  third  poorest  state  in  India  (after  Orissa 
and  Bihar).  Its  urban  population  below  the  poverty  line  was 
estimated as 38% in 2000, much higher than the national average 
of 24%. The baseline socioeconomic survey has shown that there 
are widespread deficiencies in basic urban services across the six 
project  cities.  On  average,  42.3%  of  households  do  not  have  in-
house  water  supplies  and  15.1%  do  not  have  access  to  piped 
water;  over  40%  of  households  receive  water  only  on  alternate 
days;  18.8%  of  households  do  not  have  a  private  toilet  and 
members  of  one  in  eight  households  defecate  outdoors;  32% 
report  flooding  problems;  and  40%  report  no  solid  waste 
collection.  As  a  result  the  potential  for  waterborne  and  bacterial 
diseases is high, particularly among children.  Poor infrastructure 
and  inadequate  urban  services  also  hamper  the  economic 
potential  of  the  project  cities  as  major  local  service  centers  for 
trading  and  commercial  activities  for their districts. The business 
community  indicated  that  improvements  in  basic  urban  services, 
such  as  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  management, 
are  prerequisite  for  any  improvement  in  business  performance 
and the prospect for future economic growth. 
 
The  Project  comprises  three  parts.    Part  A—urban water supply 
and  environmental  improvement—covers  the  improvement  and 
expansion  of  the  following  municipal  infrastructure  and  services: 
(i)  urban  water  supply,  (ii)  sewerage  and  sanitation,  (iii)  storm 
water drainage, and (iv) solid waste management.  Part B—public 
participation and awareness  program—is  designed to strengthen

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
The  previous  operational  strategy  for  India,  launched  in  1996,  introduced  state-level 
2. 
operations  in  a  few  reform-minded  states  to  fully  exploit  complementarities  and  synergies 
between  interventions  and  maximize  the  development  impact  in  those  states.  Typically,  the 
Asian  Development  Bank's  (ADB)  state-level  operations  have  consisted  of  a  public  resource 
management  program  to  support  fiscal  consolidation  with  programs  of  sectoral  reforms  and 
investment  in  infrastructure  sectors  like  power,  transportation,  and  urban  social  infrastructure. 
Madhya  Pradesh  was  the  second  focal  state1  selected  for  such  state-level assistance, with a 
loan for the Public Resource Management Program approved in December 1999 and followed 
by  Power  Sector  Development  Program  in  December  2000  and  State  Roads  Sector 
Development  Program  in  December  2002.  Recognizing  the  deteriorating  quality  of  municipal 
services  and  environmental  degradation  in  urban  centers,  the  government  of  the  state  of 
Madhya Pradesh requested ADB to provide financial assistance to six of the largest cities of the 
state.  
 
A. 
 

Sector Description and Performance 

1. 

The Urban Sector in Madhya Pradesh 

 
3. 
Madhya  Pradesh  geographically  is  the  heartland  of  India;  its  very  name  means  central 
state.  It  is  largely  a  rural  state  with  more  than  70%  of  its  60  million  population  in  villages  and 
working in agriculture or agriculture-related activities (Census 2001).  There are 26 towns with a 
population over 100,000 including the capital city, Bhopal. The total urban population is currently 
16.1  million  or  27%  of  the  total  population.  During  the  last  10  years  (1991-2001), population 
growth  in  the  urban  areas  was  slightly  higher  at  2.8%  per  year  compared  with  the  overall 
population growth of 2.2%. Even at a modest growth rate of 2% per year, the urban population 
is expected to reach 25 million by the end of the design period of the Project, 2021.  
  
The  bifurcation  of  the  state  into  Chhattisgarh  and  Madhya  Pradesh  in  November  2000 
4. 
meant a considerable downsizing of Madhya Pradesh in demography and economic activity as 
well as geography. Estimates indicate that 31% of the geographic area, 26% of the population, 
30%  of  mineral-rich  land  area,  and  148  large  and  medium-scale  enterprises  were  "lost"  to 
Chhattisgarh  with  the  split.  Much  of  the  urban  areas,  however,  remained  and  the  role  of  the 
urban sector in the economy has increased with reduced dependence on natural resources.  
 
5. 
Madhya  Pradesh  is  the  third  poorest  state  in  India  (after  Orissa  and  Bihar)  in  terms  of 
the  percentage  of  people  below  the  poverty  line.  The  estimated  urban  population  below  the 
poverty  line  was  38.4%  in  2000,  much  higher  than  the  national  average  of  23.6%.    Urban 
poverty, however, increased faster than rural poverty between 19942 and 2000 and, as a result, 
the incidence of poverty is now more or less the same between urban areas and rural villages.

2. 

Project Cities: Performance and Challenges 

 

a. 

Socioeconomic Context 

 
 
 
6. 
The project cities represent six of the largest municipal corporations in Madhya Pradesh. 
Bhopal  and  Indore  have  a  population  of  around  1.5  million  each.  Gwalior  and  Jabalpur  have 
between 800,000 and 1 million, and the remaining two cities, Ratlam and Ujjain have less than 
500,000 each. The total population of the six cities is 5.46 million (2001 Census), representing 
about  a  third  of  the  state’s  urban  population.  Using  a  modest  annual  growth  rate  of  2.5%  (for 
2006-2011)  and  2.25%  (for  2011-2021),  which  are  slightly  lower  than  all-India projections, the 
total population for the six project cities is estimated to be 6.9 million in 2010 and 9.1 million in 
2021.  
 
7. 
  Each  city  has  a  very  different  historical  origin,  role,  and  function  within  the  state 
(Appendix  2).  The  economic  base  and  level  of  development  are  equally  diverse,  as  are  their 
prospects for future growth and expansion. Indore and Bhopal are thriving—Indore because of 
its  position  as  the  largest  city  in  the  state,  and  its  trading  and  industrial  base;  and  Bhopal 
because of its education and position as state capital and trading and commercial center. The 
other cities are much smaller and would not be expected to have the dynamism and diversity of 
the larger cities. All cities, however, suffered in recent years from the closure or downsizing of 
the textile and other traditional industries. Many of the changes were a result of changes a shift 
in the fortunes of the sector, rather than location difficulties in Madhya Pradesh. 
 
8. 
While  industrial  estates  in  the  urban  areas  suffer  from  poor  quality  infrastructure, 
inadequate planning, and diminishing financial resources, all the project cities have potential in 
the services sector, as all are the major local service center for trading and commercial activity 
for their districts. Tourism represents another bright prospect in some project cities, as well as 
for  the  state  as  a  whole.  The  business  community,  however,  pointed  out  the  factors  that  they 
consider as prerequisite for any improvement in business performance and prospects for future 
economic growth. Access to finance was almost universally the most important factor. However, 
infrastructure  facilities,  including  power,  urban  transport,  water  supply,  sanitation  and  solid 
waste  management,  were  also  high  on  the  list.  While  power  lies  outside  the  scope  of  the 
Project, most businesses considered that improvements in basic urban services were absolutely 
necessary and that there would be direct and indirect positive outcomes from improvements in 
providing the service.  
 
 
 
In  most  of  the  project  cities,  water  supply  does  not  meet  basic  human  requirements,

differ across cities, from 30% in Bhopal and Gwalior to 80% in Ujjain. Of households with septic 
tanks, more than half report that the tanks are never cleaned and only 6% report cleaning them 
at  the  recommended  frequency  of  every  2  years.  Thus,  even  for  households  with  septic  tank 
facilities, very few are working properly.  
 
11. 
Inadequate  solid  waste  management  is  evident  in  all  project  cities.    Streets,  drainage 
channels,  and  open  areas  are  littered  with  wastes.    Residents  and  business  perceive  the 
situation  as  intolerable,  affecting  public  health  and  indirectly  affecting  economic  development, 
but  there  is  little  motivation  to  initiate  change.  Without  the  Project,  none  of  the  increasing 
quantity  of  solid  waste  will  be  adequately  disposed  of  and  at  least  40%  will  remain  on streets 
and  in  public  places.    The  current  unhygienic  conditions  will  prevail,  with  associated 
environmental degradation and public health problems. 
 
B. 
 

Urban Water Supply: Issues and Challenges 

1.  Core Issues of Urban Water Supply Sector in Madhya Pradesh 

 
12. 
In  all  project  cities,  water  from  existing  surface  water  and  groundwater  sources  is 
theoretically adequate for the present population.  However, the water produced does not reach 
the target beneficiaries largely because of operational deficiencies. In fact, all cities suffer from 
high levels of nonrevenue water. Although there is no accurate information, nonrevenue water is 
estimated  at  more  than  50%  in  all  cities.    In  particular,  technical  losses  in  the  distribution 
network are estimated to be in excess of 20%; nontechnical losses, through illegal connections, 
are also estimated to be in the same range. The losses from stand posts are thought to be very 
high as many do not work properly and large quantities of water are wasted.  The design of the 
Project is therefore based on the principle that any capital investment to expand the distribution 
network or augment the source should be preceded by system optimization to make the existing 
water supply system more efficient and economical.  
 
13.  Water  charges  for  household  connections  are  based  on  fixed  rates  and  metering  is 
undertaken in some cities only for commercial and industrial units. Except in Bhopal, the present 
monthly  charges  for  unmetered  water  connections  are  too  low  compared  with  the  cost  of 
providing services. Although the consumers are willing to pay higher prices for better services, 
the socioeconomic survey carried out under the TA showed that the record on tariff collection is 
poor  as  many  consumers  are  not  properly  charged.  The  result  is  a  chronic  shortage  of  funds 
even for basic maintenance. To make up the shortfalls in revenues, the state government in the 
past had to provide direct and indirect fiscal support for operation and maintenance (O&M). In 
line with ADB's water policy,3 the Project will promote cost recovery principles and tariff reforms 
for water conservation and its sustainable use. Consumers are expected to meet the full O&M 
costs of water facilities and service provision through modified tariff structures and rates. ADB's

A  number  of  lessons  were  learned  from  the  design  stage  to  project  implementation. 
17. 
Some  key  lessons  follow:  (i)  project  design  can  be  made  simpler  by  focusing  on  large  capital 
investments  for  basic  services,  while  the  smaller  revenue-generating  schemes  such  as 
marketplaces, sites and services, and commercial complexes can be supported by local bodies 
out  of  their  own  funds;  (ii)  since  the  sustainability  of  the  assets  created  under  the  project 
depends  on  the  level  of  ownership  and  commitment  to  reform  displayed  by  local  bodies, 
extensive interaction with local bodies is required in planning, design, and implementation; (iii) 
state governments should have a dedicated project management structure in place  from the TA 
stage and complete advance actions for recruiting of consultants before loan effectiveness; (iv) 
standard bid documents should be made mandatory across procedures, which will save several 
months of time taken for their review and approval; (v) the project management unit (PMU) must 
be  staffed  with  competent  and  experienced  personnel,  who  should  be  allowed  a  reasonable 
tenure  of  3-4  years;  (vi)  an  operational  manual  should  be  prepared  at  the  preparatory  stage 
itself,  defining  the  role  of  each  entity  in  the  implementation  framework  and  delegating  suitable 
powers, which should be followed strictly so as to avoid delays in decision making; and (vii) an 
attempt  should  be  made  to  integrate  the  poverty  reduction  components  more  closely  with 
ongoing  government  programs  and  traditional  delivery  mechanisms  at  the  local  level,  to 
maximize impact and improve sustainability.  
 
The Project is designed to reflect all these lessons learned.  The scope of the Project is

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IM PACTS, AND RISKS 

 
A. 
 

Major Benefits and Impacts 

1. 

Social and Poverty Impact 

 
56. 
The  Project  will  address  in  an  integrated  manner  citywide  deficiencies in basic needs. 
Direct social benefits will be sustained improvements in water supply, sanitation, and garbage 
collection and disposal within the project cities. Indirect benefits will be through improved living 
conditions,  a  healthier  living  environment,  and  the  prospect  of  improved  health  status  of  the 
population.  The  social  and  poverty  impact  of  the  Project  was  assessed  from  the  TA  baseline 
socioeconomic  survey  of  benefits  and  costs,  which  apply  to  different  groups  of  the  population 
within  the  six  cities.    Overall,  the  survey  respondents  identified  lack  of  access  to  a  reliable  in-
house  water  supply  as  the  foremost  deficiency.    Although  the  coverage  of  the  existing  water 
distribution network in the project cities is as high as 85%, water pressure, and frequency and 
duration of supply are extremely low.  Therefore benefits from improved efficiency of the existing 
water  supply  system  will  accrue  to  all  present  users.  In  addition,  almost  1  million  new 
consumers will gain access to piped water supply by 2010. Poor households (estimated to be 
25% of the total urban population) outside slum settlements will be fully integrated into the new 
expanded water supply system. Improved supply at slum boundaries is also an indirect benefit 
to  slum  settlements.  For  slum  dwellers  to  directly  benefit  from  the  Project,  additional 
investments are required to improve tertiary distribution within the settlements. For this purpose, 
alternative  water  supply  services  run  by  community  groups  will  be  considered.  Small-scale 
water providers can play an important role in helping the poor in slum settlements connect to the 
edge  of  the  expanded  municipal  grid  system.  For  instance,  the  water  schemes  under  the  AIF 
will  benefit  up  to  100,000  slum  dwellers  with  the  construction  of  tertiary  distribution  network 
inside the slum settlements. 
 
57. 
From  the  sanitation  component,  direct  benefits  will  be  obtained  by  households  that  will 
be able to connect to the sewerage network. The network will be located in the densely built-up 
and developing areas of the city center. The percentage of the poor households in this area is 
slightly  below  the  citywide  average  of  25%.  An  underground  sewerage  network  will,  however, 
reach  the  boundaries  of  slum  areas  within  the  scheme  area  and  will  allow the construction of 
sewered community latrines that will benefit an estimated 4% of the poor households. The solid 
waste component will operate on a citywide basis, with little difference in the standard of service 
within cities. The proportion of the poor beneficiaries is therefore the same as for each city as a 
whole.    A  summary  of  the  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in  Appendix  10.  Since  the 
Project  will  focus  on  the  urban  area,  it  will  not  adversely  affect  indigenous  peoples  or  ethnic 
minorities.

2. 

Gender Impact 

 
58. 
A  fundamental  direct  benefit  of  the  water  supply  component  will  be  the  reduction  of 
women's work in fetching, storing, and using water.  The improved levels of water delivery and 
accessibility  will  reduce  the  overall  time for collecting water and the need for storage.  During 
the  participatory  rapid  appraisal  exercise,  poor  women  cited  fetching  and  storing  water  for 
domestic use as their second priority for improvement.  The topmost priority was toilets because 
nearly  half  of  poor  women  defacate  outdoors,  one  quarter  use  public  toilets,  and  the  rest  use 
pay toilets.  Thus the provision of underground sewerage and community sanitation blocks will 
reduce  the  practice  of  defecating  outdoors,  which  is  not  only  inconvenient  but  a  cause  for 
insecurity  especially  in  unlit  and  marginal  communities.    Drainage  facilities  and  improved 
garbage collection citywide will bring indirect benefits of a healthier environment for women and  
a reduced work burden in the household.  During project implementation, a gender action plan 
(Supplementary  Appendix  J)  will  be  carried  out  to  promote  active  participation  of  women  in 
municipal management and project implementation as both beneficiaries and agents. 
 

3. 

Economic Analysis  

 
59. 
All  the  project  components  have  a  strong  economic  rationale  since  they  provide 
minimum  acceptable  standards  for  basic  living  conditions  and  assist  in  removing  existing 
constraints  on  social  development  and  economic  growth.    Similarly,  all  components  were 
designed  along  sound  principles  of  priority  need,  consultation  and  targeting,  and  demand 
management  and  rehabilitation  before  new  investment.  They  represent  technically  feasible 
options at the least cost. 
 
60. 
All six investments for the water supply component are shown to be viable although the 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) in the Indore scheme is lower at 13.3% than that in the 
other cities (ranging from 28.6% in Ujjain to 56.5% in Bhopal) because of the high capital and 
operating costs of pumping the treated water to a height of 550 meters from the river source for 
delivery  to  the  city  over  a  distance  of  70  km.  In  Indore,  which  is  a  commercial  center  and  a 
thriving  city,  the  without-the-Project  situation  could  not  be  fully  reflected  in  the  valuation  of 
benefits11(economic  analysis  is  in  Appendix  11).  For  sewerage/sanitation,  the  base  EIRRs  are 
higher than the economic cost of capital in the project cities except Gwalior and Jabalpur. Solid 
waste projects have a strong economic justification and, although the EIRR for Gwalior is shown 
to be marginal, the environmental benefits outweigh the risks of undertaking the project.

Financial  analysis  (Appendix  13)  assessed  the  viability  of  the  revenue-generating 
components  of  the  Project.  The  financial  internal  rates  of  return  (FIRRs)  for  water  supply 
schemes  vary  between  18.5%  and  5.2%  and,  combined  with  sewerage  schemes,  between 
13.4% and 4.9%, which compares favorably with the 4.0% weighted average cost of capital in

delaying project benefits by 1 year.

Environmental Aspects  

 
The Project is an environmental category B project. An initial environmental examination 
64. 
(IEE) was carried out for each project city. The examinations show that adverse environmental 
effects will be limited and can be mitigated through integrated corrective measures. A detailed 
environmental impact assessment is not required. The examinations indicate that a safe, clean, 
reliable  water  supply  and  improved  sewage  and  waste  disposal  systems  in  urban  areas  will 
significantly  improve  public  health  and  environmental  conditions  in  the  project  cities.  The 
existing  problems  of  polluted  pools  of  standing  water,  unpleasant  odors,  and  health  risks 
associated  with  increased  quantities  of  wastewater  and  haphazard  garbage  disposal  will  be 
mitigated  or  eliminated  by  integrating  water  supply  with  improved  drainage  and  sanitation 
systems, improved waste collection, and sanitary disposal as well as heightened public health 
awareness.  The  quality  of  life  and  community  health  profiles  of  the  project  cities  will  improve. 
The  disposal  of  sludge  in  the  project  water  treatment  plants  will  be  improved  by  providing 
settlement basins. 
 
65. 
There  are  no  known  endangered  varieties  of  flora  or  species  of  fauna,  or  sites  of 
historical or cultural significance in the project areas that are likely to be affected. Land areas for 
the  proposed  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  waste  management  have  been  developed  or 
disturbed previously and have no forest or unusual vegetation cover. The major impacts of the 
project  will  be  temporary,  including  those  on  health  and  safety  in  the  communities  during 
construction,  turbidity,  dust,  and  noise  generated  by  construction  equipment.  Environmental 
training will be offered to staff of the PMU and the PIUs to strengthen their capacities to address 
environmental  concerns  during  the  design  and  construction  phases  of  the  Project.  The 
contractors will be required to prepare and implement their own management plans, and carry 
out construction in line with international standards. Another measure to be implemented as part 
of the Project is enforcement of regulations for treatment and discharge of industrial wastewater.

PROJECT CITIES 

 
1. 
Bhopal  is  the  state  capital  and  the  second  largest  city  in  the  state.    Before 
independence, Bhopal was just a small town but  it grew very quickly after 1956, largely due to 
its designation as the state's capital city.  Located roughly in the middle of the state and in the 
East-West  corridor,  connectivity  by  rail,  road,  and  air  is  reasonably  good.  The  city  is  situated 
beside two lakes and is divided into two distinct parts, old Bhopal and new Bhopal.  In addition 
to its public sector role, Bhopal is a center of education and engineering among other industries 
and is also developing as a center for trade. The city became known internationally in 1984 as a 
result of the Union Carbide industrial accident.  Aftermath of the incident, new Bhopal has been 
developed with the support of the state government.  
 
Gwalior  the  fourth  largest  city,  has  its  origin  as  a  princely  state.  It  was  previously the 
2. 
capital of Scindia State and is located north of the state on the Agra-Mumbai highway.  It is a 
historic  city  and  boasts  a  dramatic  hilltop  fort,  built  more  than  1,000  years  ago.    It  has 
traditionally been an important seat of learning and culture.  As with many cities, recent years 
have seen the decline of traditional industries—mainly cotton manufacture—and the closure of 
half  of  the  city’s  large  industrial  units  and  many  smaller  units  within  the  city  boundaries.  Two 
new  industrial  estates  developed  outside  the  city  have  been  reasonably  successful.    The  city 
has  been  declared  a  counter  balance  city  of  the  National  Capital  Region  (NCR)  and  is 
developing plans to capitalize on this, but the counter balance function has yet to develop.  On 
the other side of the city, the Indian Air Force base limits expansion to the northwest.

Indore is the largest city in the state and is the business and trading capital.  Located at 
the crossroads of western and central India, Indore has relatively good connectivity by road, rail, 
and  air.    Historically,  Indore  was  always  a  trading  center,  particularly  for  foodstuffs,  and  has 
been the hub of trade and commerce, not only for the state, but also for western India. Since the 
decline of its traditional industries including textiles, the economic base of Indore has changed 
considerably.  The city holds a dominant position in wholesale trading and as a transshipment 
center for the surrounding regions.  Trade and commerce, the financial sector, and new higher 
tech companies have come to replace the older industries. 
 
Jabalpur is the third largest city in the state.  Located east of Madhya Pradesh, Jabalpur

Gwalior,  it  originated  as  the  capital  of  a  princely  state.    Ratlam  is  located  in  the  East-West 
corridor, on the main Delhi-Mumbai highway and railroad.  The city has grown as an important 
railway junction on the Delhi-Mumbai line and as a service city for the surrounding hinterland for 
wholesale  trading  in  agriculture  commodities  and  other  agriculture-related  activities.    Railway 
employees  constitute  the  majority  of  the  workforce  (around  19,000)  and,  together  with 
government  employees  and  their  families,  account  for  about  half  the  city  population.    Recent 
years  have  seen  the  closure  of  an  estimated  80%  of  industry,  including  the  only  large  factory

Ujjain,  once  the  seat  of  the  ancient  kingdom  of  Vikramaditya,  is  an  important  religious, 
educational, and cultural center and a destination of millions of Hindu pilgrims.  Besides regular 
visitors (about 200,000-300,000 per year), once every 12 years there is a flood of devotees to 
the  city  (an  estimated  5  million  in  2004).    About  an  hour  by  road  from  Indore,  the  city,  once 
important for cotton manufacture, has suffered considerable decline.  All four of the cotton mills 
closed over 10 years ago and there is little alternative for the 7,000 strong workforce retrenched.  
Religious  tourism,  services  for  the  local  population,  and  some  small-scale industries including 
power and hand looms and packaging are the mainstays of the city’s economy.

The Asian Development Bank's (ADB) poverty reduction strategy defines poverty as a deprivation of essential assets to 
which  every  human  is  entitled.  The  strategy  includes  access to water, sanitation, and other basic services, as well as 
employment income and wages, as measures of poverty.  The assessment of the prevailing situation in India, Madhya 
Pradesh, and the project cities has revealed the poor quality of the urban environment infrastructure and a demonstrable 
gap in the provision of basic services, to the poor in particular. 
 
The Project will address deficiencies of basic needs citywide in an integrated manner. Direct benefits will be sustained 
improvements  in  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  management  six  project  cities.  Indirect  benefits  will  be 
through  improved  living  conditions,  a  healthier  living  environment,  and  the  prospect  of  improved  health  status  of  the 
population.  The  poverty  impact  of  the  Project  was  assessed  from  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA) 
baseline socioeconomic survey in terms of benefits and costs, which apply to different groups of the population the six 
cities.    Overall,  the  survey  respondents  identified  lack  of  access  to  a  reliable  in-house water supply as the foremost 
deficiency.  Although  the  coverage  of  the  existing  water  distribution  network  in  the  six  cities  is  as  high  as  85%,  water 
pressure, and the frequency and duration of supply are extremely poor.  Therefore, benefits of improved efficiency of the 
existing  water  supply  system  will  accrue  to  all  existing  users,  including  the  poor.  In  addition,  almost  1  million  new 
consumers will gain access to piped water supply by 2010. While the poor households (estimated to be  25% of the total 
urban  population)  outside  slum  settlements  will  be  fully  integrated  into  the  new  expanded  water  supply  system,  the 
benefits to slum settlements will be initially indirect in terms of improved supply at the slum boundaries. For the slum 
dwellers to directly benefit from the Project, additional investments are required to improve tertiary distribution within the 
slum  settlements.  For  instance,  the  water  schemes  under  the  AIF  will  benefit  up  to  100,000  slum  dwellers,  which  is 
about 7% of the total slum population.  
 
Direct  benefits  from  the  sanitation  component  will  be  obtained  by  households  that  will  be  able  to  connect  to  the 
sewerage network. The network will be in the densely built-up and developing areas of the city center. The percentage of 
poor  households  in  this  area  is  slightly  below  the  citywide  average  of  the  poor  households  (25%).  The  underground 
sewerage  network  will,  however,  reach  the  boundaries  of  slum  areas  within  the  scheme  area  and  this  will  enable  the 
provision  of  sewered  community  latrines  that  will  benefit  an  estimated  4%  of  the  poor  households.  The  solid  waste 
component will operate citywide with little difference in the standard of service within cities. The proportion of the poor 
beneficiaries is therefore the same for each city as a whole.

India’s  urban  population  of  about  285  million  is  expected  to  almost  double  to  550  million  over  the  next  20  years,  an 
average addition of more than 11 million new urban residents each year. The incidence of poverty in India remains high 
although both the absolute numbers and proportion of people living below the poverty line are falling. The proportion of 
the  total  population  living  below  the  poverty  line  in  2001  is  estimated at 26% or a population of 268 million. In urban 
areas, the population below the poverty line is estimated at 24%, or about 67 million, slightly better than in rural areas. 
 
In  Madhya  Pradesh,  the  estimated  urban  population  below  the  poverty  line  was  38% in 2000, much higher than the 
national  average  of  24%.    Urban  poverty,  however,  dropped  faster  than  rural  poverty  between  1994  (44%)  and  2000 
and, as a result, the incidence of poverty is now lower in urban areas than in rural villages, where 44% of the population 
still live below the poverty line. Among the urban poor, the slum population, counted for the first time during the 2001 
Census,  totaled  more  than  2.3  million,  representing  24%  of  the  urban  population,  which  is  slightly  higher  than  the 
national average of 21%.  
 
Other than these primary data published by the Central Government, there is very little state-level data that can support 
an analysis of vulnerability among the urban poor. Almost no secondary data exist, which can permit an analysis of other 
dimensions of urban poverty, particularly health, social capital, and gender disparity. To fill up such data gap, a baseline 
socioeconomic  survey  covering  a  total  of  9,600  households  was  undertaken  during  the  TA.  The  survey  was 
complemented by a series of participatory exercises including participatory rapid appraisal, focus group discussions, and 
municipal workshops.

2. 
Consideration of alternatives and preference for least-cost solutions are one of the main 
design  principles  of  the  Project.  Assessment  covered  a  mix  of  technical,  social,  and 
environmental as well as financial considerations.  For the water supply component, alternatives 
included (i) groundwater versus surface water—surface water is preferred as Madhya Pradesh 
is  semiarid  and  recharge  is  not  assured;  (ii)  different  water  sources—considerations included 
distance, yield, sustainability, and transmission cost; and (iii) water treatment processes —rapid 
sand filter is preferred to slow sand filtration. In all cases the most technically appropriate and 
least-cost solution was selected.  
 
3. 
For  the  sewerage/sanitation  component,  alternatives  considered  for  the  proposed 
reticulated systems included combined versus separate systems; network choices of pumping 
versus gravity, size of  pipe  and  routing;  and  larger  geographic  areas.    Separate  systems  and 
network  choices  of  gravity  were  selected  primarily  due  to  lower  cost.    For  sewage  treatment 
plants,  alternative  processes  and  sites  were  considered.    Waste  stabilization  ponds  were 
chosen  on  grounds  of  the  least  capital  requirement  and  operational  costs  although  the  land 
requirement is higher.  
 
4. 
Alternative  processes  for  municipal  waste  disposal  were  considered  based  on  the 
analysis  of  composition  in  each  city.  The  processes  included  incineration,  turning  waste  to 
energy,  composting,  and  sanitary  landfill.    The  composition  of  the  waste  stream  in  the  project 
cities  is  not  appropriate  for  direct  incineration  or  waste-to-energy  schemes  as  it  has  a  low 
carbon and combustible quality and the moisture content is too high, especially in the monsoon 
season.  Composting is feasible but requires the segregation of appropriate organic sources of 
waste material, preferably at source, plus the development of a market for the final product.  As 
waste  collection  processes  improve  under  the  Project,  composition  is  likely  to  change,  but  a 
sanitary landfill is the only technical and economically viable option in the near future.

wastewater surcharge on water bills. Benefits and costs were kept constant after FY2021 when 
all facilities would be operating at near full capacity and present design demands would be fully

Introduction 

Description of the Project 

A. 
 
An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  undertaken as part of the Urban Water 
1. 
Supply  and  Environmental  Improvement  Project  in  Madhya  Pradesh  to  ascertain  the  Project's 
impact  on  the  environment  and  to  identify  measures  to  prevent  or  mitigate  any  adverse 
environmental impacts that could arise from its implementation.  
 
2. 
The  Project  is  categorized  as  a  “B”  Project  in  accordance  with  Asian  Development 
Bank's (ADB) Guidelines on Environmental Assessment. All subcomponents aim to improve the 
quality  and  security  of  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  waste  disposal.  IEEs  carried  out  for  all 
subcomponents  showed  no  significant  environmental  effect.  Project  activities  that  may  have  a 
marginally significant effect, and the main mitigation measures proposed are summarized here.  
 
B. 
 
3. 
The major cities of Madhya Pradesh are lagging behind comparable cities elsewhere in 
India, in the level and quality of basic infrastructure and services. Fundamental needs such as a 
reliable water supply, adequate sewerage and sanitation, and effective means for collecting and 
disposing  of  solid  waste  are  not  satisfied.  The  Project  is  designed  to  enhance  the  minimum 
prerequisites  for  economic  development  and  contribute  urban  poverty  reduction  and  improved 
health and hygiene. The details of the Project are in the main text of the report. 
 
C. 
 
4. 
The  Project  covers  the  six  larger  urban  centers  (Bhopal,  Gwalior,  Indore,  Jabalpur, 
Ratlam, and Ujain) of the state of Madhya Pradesh, with populations from 250,000 to 1.5 million. 
The cities are centers of administration, commerce, and industry, with environmental problems 
similar to those affecting most large cities in the subcontinent: (i) lack of continuous and reliable 
water supply; (ii) lack of an adequate network for disposing of storm water or wastewater; and 
(iii)  general  widespread  pollution  caused  by  improper  disposal  of  human,  domestic,  and 
industrial waste. Provision of basic services is particularly deficient in the slum areas, and other 
informal residential areas without planned essential infrastructure throughout the project cities.  
 
5. 
The  state  of  Madhya  Pradesh  has  many  forests,  especially  in  the  Vindhya-Kaimar, the 
Satpura and Maikala ranges, and the Baghelkhand plateau. Wildlife sanctuaries are at Kanha, 
Shivpuri,  Bandhavgarh  and  Rewa.  There  are  no  fisheries,  wildlife,  forest,  and  rare  or 
endangered species in or around the project cities. Land areas for the proposed water supply, 
sewage  treatment  facilities,  and  waste  disposal  facilities  have  been  developed  or  disturbed 
previously and have no forest or unusual vegetation cover.  
 
6. 
There are no known sites of historical or cultural significance in the areas that are likely 
to  be  affected  during  project  implementation.  In  the  detailed  investigation  and  design  of  water 
and  sanitation  works,  particular  care  will  be  taken  to  identify  historical  and  cultural  sites,  and 
appropriate steps taken to protect them.
